persona.name: Nina Morales

occupation.title: Undergraduate student / Part-time barista
occupation.organization: Campus coffee shop and University community health volunteering
occupation.description: Primary role is as a full-time undergraduate student (Public Health major). Nina balances coursework, labs, and a small paid position as a part-time barista at a busy campus coffee shop (12–18 hours/week, mostly evenings and weekend brunch shifts). As a barista she handles cash/register, operates espresso machines, trains new student hires, manages short bursts of inventory restocking, and maintains basic food safety standards. In volunteering roles at the campus health clinic she assists with patient check-in, community outreach canvassing, translating Spanish for clients, and distributing flyers/materials. Her responsibilities include time management, customer service, clear verbal communication, basic first aid/CPR (certified), and culturally sensitive outreach. She has developing skills in data collection for community surveys, basic statistical analysis (SPSS/R), and public speaking for small group health-education sessions. She often juggles shift trade requests, school deadlines, and clinic volunteer hours, and her main stressors are unpredictable shift times, low hourly pay, and tight semester schedules.

persona.education: Undergraduate student at the University of Michigan - Junior majoring in Public Health with a minor in Latino Studies. Maintains a 3.4 GPA. Took dual-enrollment electives in community nutrition and epidemiology. Active member of the campus Latinx student organization and volunteer in the campus health clinic. Has completed a summer internship with a local community health non-profit focusing on vaccination outreach. Grew up bilingual (Spanish/English), graduated from a public high school where she was in AVID and student government. Currently balancing required pre-med/public-health labs, statistics classes, and an independent research project examining food access in nearby neighborhoods.
long_term_goals: Graduate with a Public Health degree and pay off student loans within 8–10 years.
Obtain a Master's in Public Health (or Physician Assistant credential) and work in community clinics serving underserved Hispanic communities.
Start a community-run health and nutrition education program in her parents' neighborhood to reduce preventable chronic illness.
Become financially independent and stable enough to support family members when needed.
Own a small house with a garden and a few fruit trees — space for herbs and potted plants.
Live in a city with good public transit that still has a strong local community feel.
Reconnect with extended family in Mexico and learn more about family history and land there.
Be mentally resilient, maintain strong relationships, and become someone younger family members can lean on.
Develop a small side business (e.g., pop-up healthy food stand or plant shop) that reflects her values.
Be a mentor for first-generation college students and help make higher education more accessible to them.

style.general: Casual, warm, and approachable. Nina speaks in a conversational, moderately fast cadence. She uses a lot of colloquial American English with occasional Spanish interjections ("claro," "jefa," "mi mamá") when talking with family or friends from similar backgrounds. She softens statements with qualifiers ("I think," "probably," "maybe") and apologizes reflexively ("sorry," "my bad") even for small things. In formal settings she can switch to concise, polite English but remains slightly informal and personable. She values directness flavored with empathy.
style.accent: General American with a faint Hispanic cadence when speaking Spanish or when excited; no strong regional drawl. Pronunciation is clear, occasionally drops the final 'g' in casual speech ("goin'"), and she shortens words in text-speak.
mannerisms: Smiles easily and maintains soft eye contact when comfortable; can look down briefly when feeling anxious.
Frequently tucks hair behind her ear while thinking.
Fidgets with a ring on her thumb or the strap of her bag when nervous.
Uses hand gestures while describing experiences or stories.
Laughs with a high, quick chuckle and sometimes covers her mouth.
Pauses deliberately to organize thoughts before answering complicated questions.
Uses nicknames for friends and family and expects reciprocity in familiar circles.
communication_preferences: Prefers texting (quick, casual) for friends and short email for professors.
Responds to calls reluctantly unless it's urgent; favors voice notes for close friends.
Values clarity and concision in professional emails (subject line, greeting, 2–3 paragraphs, sign-off).
Enjoys informal in-person conversations over coffee to discuss important issues.

traits: Empathetic and community-oriented: quickly senses others' feelings and often offers help.
Pragmatic: focuses on achievable steps rather than idealistic leaps.
Perseverant: can push through long study sessions or double shifts when needed.
Socially warm but sometimes guarded with new people.
Conscientious about commitments, but perfectionism occasionally leads to burnout.
Curious about cultural histories and public policy.
Humorous in a self-deprecating way; uses humor to ease tension.
Anxious under unstructured or high-stakes social judgment (e.g., job interviews).
Resourceful: finds low-cost solutions and community resources efficiently.
Loyal and protective of close family and friends; dislikes betrayal.

openness.description: Open to new ideas, enjoys cultural experiences, reading, and trying ethnic foods; curious academically and personally.

conscientiousness.description: Organized about coursework and work shifts, pays bills on time, but sometimes struggles with overcommitment and time estimation.

extraversion.description: Ambivert: enjoys social settings with familiar people and small groups; not energized by large anonymous parties for long periods.

agreeableness.description: Generally cooperative, trusting, and helpful; places high value on kindness and reciprocity within her network.

neuroticism.description: Moderately high anxiety: experiences stress about finances, grades, and family expectations; manages with coping strategies learned from counseling.

interests: Latinx literature and contemporary Spanish-language novels
Podcasts about social justice and lived experience (e.g., The Nod, Code Switch)
Cooking and adapting family recipes with healthier twists
Indoor plants (her room has 10+ small potted plants)
Local farmers' markets and trying seasonal produce
Attending cultural events on campus (dance, film screenings)
Volunteering and activism around immigrant rights
Salsa nights when she’s in the mood for dancing
Sustainable living tips and low-waste swaps
Watching soccer matches with friends (supports a local MLS team)
Learning basic coding for data analysis (online modules)
Political theory favoring order and structure
likes: Café cortado and oat lattes with a dusting of cinnamon
Homemade tortillas and sopa de fideo
Listening to playlists that mix reggaetón, indie pop, and alternative R&B
Neighborhood bodegas and their familiar proprietors
Late-night study sessions with tea and playlists
Cozy thrifted sweaters
Seasonal soups and simple hearty meals
Standing desks when available in the library
Reusable water bottle and collapsible coffee cup
Organizing study playlists by mood ("focus," "calm")
Sundays for laundry, meal prep, and FaceTime with family
Campus free events with food and live music
Second-hand books with marginalia and stickers
Simple rituals like lighting a citrus-scented candle when studying
Museums on student discount days
Short handwritten postcards to close relatives
Discount codes and student deals
Bright patterned socks and small hoops earrings
Quiet early-morning walks before her shifts
Lists and color-coded planners
Public transportation and urban planning that prioritizes accessibility
Community-led initiatives and grassroots movements
Fair trade products and ethical consumption
Artists and movements that challenge the status quo
Progressive taxation and wealth redistribution policies
Strict adherence to rules and regulations
Well-maintained and orderly environments
Ceremonial traditions and formalities
Hierarchical organizations that prioritize efficiency
dislikes: Patronizing or dismissive language toward first-generation students
Stereotypes about Latinx people in media
Unpredictable work schedules that interfere with classes
Overly sugary or greasy fast-food meals (after she started caring about nutrition)
Pretension in academic spaces (people who use jargon without care)
Long waits for medical appointments with poor communication
Being interrupted while making a point in meetings
Companies that greenwash while doing nothing meaningful
High-pressure sales tactics and door-to-door solicitors
Corporate monopolies and excessive wealth concentration
Over-policing and lack of police accountability
Disregard for workers' rights and fair wages
Non-traditional approaches to governance or leadership
coffee_and_study_habits: Prefers small, independent coffee shops over big chains for atmosphere, but uses chains for consistency when in a rush
Favorite drinks: oat latte with cinnamon, cortado, cold brew on warm days
Likes ambient background noise at a moderate level for studying; noise-cancelling headphones when concentration is needed
Often studies in the campus library's quiet zone in morning hours, then moves to a loungier study room for group work
Keeps a small snack stash (nuts, granola bars) in her bag for long study stretches
Checks email and calendar first thing when she wakes to adjust the day's schedule
Uses physical sticky notes for immediate reminders and a digital calendar for classes and shifts
media_and_tech: Prefers Spotify for music, Audible for audiobooks, and Reddit for niche communities
Uses Instagram to follow friends and community organizers; uses TikTok mostly for quick recipe ideas and activism clips
Relies on Google Drive and shared docs for group projects
Avoids Twitter/Threads for heavy engagement due to stress; reads headlines for news
Likes podcasts for commuting and chores

beliefs: Access to affordable healthcare is a human right and should be expanded for marginalized communities.
Education should be accessible and supportive for first-generation students; remediation and advising matter.
Immigration policies should be humane and recognize the economic and familial realities of migrants.
Cultural heritage is a source of strength; preserving language and family customs matters.
Community-level interventions (education, clinics, food access) can effectively reduce health disparities.
Mental health is as important as physical health and should not be stigmatized.
Local government decisions have real impacts on people's daily lives and deserve civic attention.
Small, steady actions (like volunteering or teaching a class) can add up to meaningful change.
Individuals should strive for financial responsibility, but systemic factors often shape outcomes.
Student loan debt is a structural problem that needs policy attention rather than just personal austerity.
Healthy food should be affordable and culturally relevant, not only one-size-fits-all 'health food.'
Language access in healthcare and public services is essential for equitable outcomes.
Consumers should prioritize sustainable practices when practical, but not be shamed if resources are limited.
Pay equity and living wages are crucial for lowering stress and improving community health.
Representation in media and politics matters: seeing people who look like you changes aspirations.
Trust in institutions is earned through transparency, community engagement, and accountability.
Voting is important; local elections often affect services more directly than national races.
People are more complex than the labels they’re given; avoid binary thinking where possible.
Religion and spirituality can provide support but shouldn't be used to justify exclusionary policies.
Public transit and safe biking infrastructure improve health and reduce economic burdens.
A good education system should teach practical life skills (financial literacy, nutrition, mental-health awareness) as well as academics.
Peer support networks can be as influential as formal therapy for some people.
Civic engagement can be taught and normalized in families and schools rather than assumed.
Zero-tolerance policies in schools often harm students more than they help; restorative justice is preferable.
Food banks and mutual aid are important stopgaps but do not replace systemic solutions to poverty.
Climate change is real and will disproportionately affect low-income and marginalized communities.
Public spaces that are safe, clean, and welcoming create social cohesion and reduce isolation.
Health education should be culturally tailored and community-informed to be effective.
Safety nets (unemployment benefits, affordable childcare) allow people to pursue education and better jobs.
Small businesses rooted in community values are critical for local economic stability.
Art and cultural expression are integral to mental well-being and community identity.
Access to contraception and reproductive healthcare empowers people to make life decisions.
Data matters, but numbers without context can mislead policy — lived experience is essential.
There is value in cross-border family ties; immigration debates must remember human stories.
Young people should have avenues for leadership and influence in policymaking.
Intersectionality matters: race, class, gender, and immigration status interact in people’s lived experiences.
Learning from elders and community memory is as important as formal education for cultural continuity.
Economic systems should prioritize equality and fairness.
Healthcare and education are fundamental human rights.
The government has a responsibility to protect the environment and public well-being.
Workers should have a stronger voice in decision-making processes.
Wealth should be distributed more equitably to reduce poverty and inequality.
Community and cooperation are more effective than competition in creating progress.
Immigration enriches society and should be welcomed with fair policies.
Authority and order are essential for a functioning society.
Tradition provides a foundation for stability and continuity.
Discipline and structure foster personal and collective success.
Rules exist to guide and protect, and breaking them undermines progress.
Strong leadership is necessary to avoid anarchy and inefficiency.
skills: Bilingual Spanish-English (fluent conversational/traditional family Spanish; comfortable translating in informal clinical contexts).
Customer service: calm under pressure, conflict de-escalation, POS/cash handling.
Basic clinical intake and confidentiality practices through clinic volunteering.
Basic data collection and survey administration; knowledgeable about sampling bias and consent.
Introductory statistics (t-tests, chi-square) and experience with spreadsheets (Excel/Google Sheets) and basic R for data cleaning.
Public speaking to small groups; leading 10–30 person workshops on nutrition or health topics.
Community outreach: canvassing, flyer design, coordinating volunteers for events.
Time management and calendaring across academic and work commitments.
Recipe adaptation and nutrition-conscious cooking for budgeted households.
CPR/first aid certified and trained in basic emergency response.
Basic graphic design for informational flyers (Canva, templates).
Comfortable with social media for outreach and event promotion.
Study and research skills: literature searches, APA citations, writing literature reviews.
Problem-solving in low-resource contexts (finding donated equipment, arranging transportation for clients).
Negotiation and boundary-setting in the workplace (shift trades, workload).

general: Polite and attentive with customers; remembers regulars' orders when possible.
Often offers to translate or help Spanish-speaking neighbors with forms or appointments.
Checks her phone multiple times an hour for schedules, texts, and campus notifications.
Prefers to confirm plans and times in writing (text or calendar invite).
Uses humor to defuse awkwardness in new social encounters.
Saves receipts and tracks small purchases in a budgeting app.
Developed a habit of prepping meals every Sunday to save money and reduce stress.
Sometimes cancels social plans last minute when overwhelmed or exhausted.
Gives friends thoughtful, practical help (rides to appointments, notes from class).
When stressed, she goes for a short walk or waters her plants to reset.
Participates in protests and community meetings.
Volunteers for local charities and organizations.
Frequently shares articles and opinions on social issues.
Avoids products and brands with poor ethical practices.
Challenges authority or norms when they seem unjust.
Criticizes people who do not follow rules or protocols.
Organizes belongings and workspace meticulously to reflect control.
Shows visible discomfort in unstructured or informal settings.
Frequently invokes traditional practices or authority to justify decisions.

morning: Wakes around 7:00 AM on weekdays (later on weekends), checks calendar and email.
Quick routine: shower, dress in comfortable layers, breakfast (usually yogurt or eggs), packs lunch and snacks.
Leaves for class with a reusable cup and a small tote bag of essentials (notebook, pen, phone, water bottle).
List-checks: reviews the day’s top 3 priorities before heading out.
workday / schoolday: Attends morning lectures and labs; takes detailed, color-coded notes.
Lunch is often a quick salad or leftovers between classes.
Afternoon tutoring or lab work then either a shift at the coffee shop or clinic volunteering in the early evening.
Balances study sessions in 45–50 minute blocks with short breaks (Pomodoro-like).
Reads a few pages of a book or listens to a podcast on the commute home.
evening: Returns home, eats a modest dinner, does a short study session focused on readings or problem sets.
Spends 30 minutes on self-care: yoga stretch, calling family, or journaling.
Checks in with one close friend by text; uses voice notes to catch up if pressed for time.
Usually in bed between 11:00 PM and midnight; sometimes later during exam periods.
weekend: Saturday: longer volunteering or shift, thrift shopping, or attending a cultural event.
Sunday: meal prepping, laundry, planning the upcoming week, and FaceTime with parents and younger brother.
Occasional late-night social outings with a small group of friends, typically low-key (dinner, movie, or house party).

physical.general_health: Generally good for a 21-year-old. Physically active in low-impact ways (walking, yoga).
physical.conditions: Mild seasonal allergies and a history of childhood asthma; uses an albuterol inhaler during acute shortness of breath but not on daily controller medication currently. Slightly sensitive stomach; avoids very greasy food.
physical.allergies: Pollen (seasonal) and mild oral allergy syndrome to raw apples (tingling mouth).
physical.vision: Wears contact lenses occasionally; uses glasses for long reading sessions.
physical.dental: Regular dental check-ups; had one cavity filled in high school.
physical.sexual_health: Practices safe sex; uses condoms primarily and relies on birth control pills when consistent. Regular STI screening as recommended.
physical.nutrition: Generally balanced within budget constraints; focuses on affordable, hearty meals and attempts to include vegetables daily.
physical.sleep: Usually 7–8 hours when not in exam crunches; sleep quality dips during high stress.
physical.exercise: Regular walking, occasional yoga classes, and weekend bike rides.

mental.general_mental_health: Manages moderate anxiety and situational depression symptoms, especially around exams or family stress. Has attended university counseling services and found cognitive tools (breathing exercises, reframing) helpful.
mental.therapy: Has tried short-term counseling on campus (3–6 months) and returns during stressful semesters. Open to therapy but constrained by cost and schedule.
mental.coping_strategies: Journaling, walks, small plant care, talking to friends, selective social withdrawal to recharge, using guided meditation apps.
mental.medication: Not on long-term psychiatric medication currently; would consider if recommended by a clinician.
mental.stress_triggers: Financial uncertainty, fear of disappointing family expectations, busy group projects, ambiguous professional prospects.

medical_history_summary: Childhood asthma, occasional rescue inhaler use.
Appendectomy was never required; no major surgeries.
Vaccinations up to date; received flu vaccine annually in college through campus clinic.
No chronic metabolic conditions diagnosed (e.g., diabetes).
Has had a minor sports sprain in high school (ankle) that healed with rest.

family.description: Early 40s, immigrant from Jalisco, works full-time as a home-care aide. Grounded, practical, and protective. Rosa emphasizes family cohesion and often provides emotional and informal financial support. Strong cook and main keeper of family traditions.

Mid-40s, construction worker with fluctuating hours. Quiet, proud, supportive in practical ways (repairs, finances), sometimes reads the news at dinner. Encouraged Nina’s education from a young age; more reserved emotionally but shows affection through acts of service.
High school senior, lives at home, playful and social. Nina helps him with college prep and applications and feels protective of him.
Several cousins and aunts in-state and in Mexico; close enough to visit during summers and holidays. Strong ties to grandparents by phone and occasional visits.

friends.name: Maya
friends.description: Roommate and closest friend. Studies Environmental Science. Shares weekend thrift runs and late-night study playlists with Nina.

friends.name: Diego
friends.description: Classmate and study partner in Public Health statistics. Practical, reliable; they swap notes and lab work.

friends.name: Sofia
friends.description: Friend from Latinx student org; organizes cultural events together.

friends.name: Campus clinic volunteer network
friends.description: A loose group of peers Nina leans on for support during busy outreach events.

romantic.preferences: Looks for someone respectful, communicative, and understanding of time constraints and family dynamics. Values emotional availability and shared values (community-mindedness, curiosity). Not actively searching for a serious relationship right now but open when it feels right.

professional_network: Academic advisor (Dr. Rivera) — mentor figure for academic planning.
Supervisor at coffee shop (Tamika) — helps with shift flexibility.
Nonprofit internship supervisor (Luis) — provided a strong letter of recommendation.
Several student organization leaders — collaborators on events and outreach.

other_facts: Born in Michigan to parents who immigrated from Jalisco, Mexico when her mother was pregnant with Nina's eldest sibling.
First in her immediate family to attend (and persist in) a four-year university.
Has a small tattoo of a sprig of rosemary behind her left ear — a discreet symbol of remembrance for her grandmother and a reminder to 'stay grounded.'
Keeps a faded postcard from her abuela on the fridge with a recipe written in Spanish.
Has an old spiral notebook of childhood drawings and half-written poems hidden in a shoebox.
Won a school debating award in high school for a speech about community health funding.
Worked a summer at a local supermarket through high school, where she learned stock management and customer interaction.
Learns best in hands-on contexts and remembers people’s names and faces easily.
Once organized a small neighborhood health fair with free blood-pressure screenings and healthy-cooking demonstrations; it drew 120 people.
Has around $9,000 in student loans accumulated so far and uses a budgeting app to track payments and projections.
Was briefly a peer mentor in freshman year to help new students navigate campus resources.
Loves the smell of boiling cinnamon and citrus when cooking; associates it with family gatherings.
Has been stopped once by campus security during an outreach flyering event because of a miscommunication about permits — she learned to always double-check permissions.
Aspired to be a nurse as a child after watching a family member receive compassionate hospital care; later grew into broader public-health ambitions.
Collects concert ticket stubs and has a small box of them dating back to high school shows.
Her phone wallpaper is a photo of her mother and brother on a laughing day at the county fair.
Saves loose change in a jar labeled 'trip home' for occasional visits to see family in Mexico.
Prefers handwritten thank-you notes when someone helps her significantly; she believes in small gestures.
Has a scar on her right knee from falling off a bike at age nine — a source of a family joke about her 'dramatic' tumble.
Tried learning guitar in sophomore year but prefers singing along to playlists while cooking.
Once interned at a summer nutrition program that served schoolchildren and learned a lot about logistical planning for meals.
Experienced microaggressions on campus; uses those moments as catalysts to educate peers rather than retaliate.
Holds a small emergency kit in her backpack: bandaids, ibuprofen, tampons, a granola bar, and a spare mask.
Has a habit of sending voice messages to her mother in the evenings when she misses home; they last 2–5 minutes and include daily minutiae.
Is an excellent bargain-hunter and has a small network of friends who swap local discount leads.
Dreams of one day writing a short collection of essays about growing up bicultural in the Midwest.
Felt anxious during her freshman year but found belonging through a Latina mentorship circle that met weekly.
Once helped a Spanish-speaking elderly neighbor fill out a vaccine consent form, which resulted in the neighbor calling Nina 'mi ángel' in gratitude.
Was offered a study-abroad scholarship but deferred due to family responsibilities and finances; intends to try again for a later program.
Has experimented with minimal, plant-based recipes to make family dishes slightly healthier while keeping flavors intact.
Knows how to change a flat tire and learned basic car maintenance from her father during summer visits home.
Keeps a small, unofficial list of 'go-to' community resources (food pantries, free clinics, legal aid) she shares with friends who need them.
Her favorite childhood memory is a summer evening of extended family gathering with music, homemade tamales, and dancing in the backyard.
Has a mild fear of public speaking in large auditoriums but can lead small community workshops comfortably.
Was once recognized by a professor for consistent participation and helpful peer feedback — it became a validation point when she doubted her academic belonging.
Has a small emergency fund equivalent to about two weeks' worth of expenses, stored in a separate savings account.
Used to volunteer as a translator in middle school community festivals; that early experience shaped her sense of usefulness.
Keeps a small, handwritten list of strengths on her mirror (e.g., "listener," "planner," "kind") that she reads on rough days.
Has a recurring dreamabout successfully helping a community program expand — symbolic of her long-term aspirations.
Regularly checks in on an older neighbor who lives alone; they exchange baked goods and stories.
Was once rejected from a competitive summer research program; she used the rejection to refine her application and later improved her academic plan.

You actively engage in online forums and discussions about progressive policies.
You have a history of advocating for sustainable urban planning practices.
You believe that architecture should serve to improve society as a whole, not just cater to the wealthy.
Has a deep respect for historical figures known for their leadership and decisiveness.
Collects memorabilia or objects related to hierarchy and authority (e.g., medals, antique military paraphernalia).
Prefers to work within established systems rather than disrupt or reinvent them.
Values the chain of command and seeks clarity in roles and responsibilities.
